==The Scientific Perspective On ‘Wisdom’==
  +   +
Scientifically, ‘wisdom’ is a specific stage along the scientific learning pathway, using the scientific method.
  +
• Scientifically, ‘learning’ is defined as ‘changing the meaning of life experience’, and
  +
• ‘scientific-learning’ is defined as ‘changing the meaning of life experience through the appropriate use of the scientific method’.
  +
• The ‘scientific method’ is one of many different ways of learning about the universe around us (and the universe inside of each of us) and contains the following basic steps:
  +
• Questions
  +
• Hypotheses
  +
• Predictions
  +
• Design Of Controlled Scientific Experiments
  +
• Collecting Experimental Results
  +
• Proper Interpretation of Experimental Evidence
  +
• Sharing Results & Methods Truthfully With Others à
  +
• Checking For Reproducibility By Others
  +
• Asking New Questions
  +   +
‘Wisdom’ is currently viewed as the fourth stage in a DIKW-based approach to the scientific-learning process.
  +
• The first stage starts with the infinite facts of the universe around us (and the universe inside of each of us): Fortunately, most of these facts are functionally silent. This stage is termed ‘Scientific- Data’.
  +
• The second stage is a specific grouping of data that places a demand upon the attention of the observer: This stage is termed ‘Scientific-Information’. (Some experts define ‘scientific-information’ as ‘scientific-data in context’).
  +
• The third stage is a specific grouping of information that allows the observer to predict responses: This stage is termed ‘Scientific-Knowledge’. (Some experts define ‘scientific-knowledge’ as ‘scientific-information in context’).
  +
• The fourth stage in this distillation process is a specific grouping of scientific-knowledge, known as ‘Scientific-Wisdom’. The exact definition of ‘Scientific-Wisdom’ is somewhat difficult to describe precisely: Certainly, whereas ‘scientific-wisdom’ could be viewed as ‘scientific-knowledge in context’, this definition does not convey the operational sense of the term.
  +
o Perhaps Jonas Salk, the pioneering 20th Century scientist who is credited for discovering the first cure for poliomyelitis, has performed the most elegant recent studies of ‘Scientific-Wisdom’.
  +
o In brief, Salk (and now many others) are viewing ‘Scientific-Wisdom’ as possessing 5 basic components:
  +
o Personal Passion for Scientific Interest Area
  +
o Skills-Competence in Scientific Interest Area
  +
o Purpose in Scientific Skills-Execution
  +
o Ability To Sponsor Hi-Value Collective Mastery
  +
Experiences In Science
  +
o Talent in Seeking Solutions That Satisfy Man –
  +
And Do Not Violate The Laws of Nature
  +   +   +
It would certainly be impossible to properly conduct modern 21st Century scientific operations without a clear understanding of
  +
• ‘Scientific-Data’,
  +
• ‘Scientific-Information’, and
  +
• ‘Scientific-Knowledge’.
  +
It is becoming increasingly clear, in our increasingly interconnected science and technology-oriented planet, that ‘Scientific-Wisdom’ is the next step in the DIKW-based learning pathway: Moreover, ‘Scientific-Wisdom’ is becoming increasingly valued as representing a refined level of scientific understanding.
